comments: For prime n, a(n) = n-1. Question: do nonprimes exist with this property?Answer: No. If n is composite then a(n) < n-1. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 09 2013Lehmer's totient problem (1932): are there composite numbers n such that a(n) = phi(n)? - _Thomas Ordowski_, Nov 08 2015a(n) = 1 for n in A209211. - _Robert Israel_, Nov 09 2015
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, B37.
links: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Lehmer's Totient Problem
formula: a(p^m) = a(p) = p-1 for prime p and m > 0. - _Thomas Ordowski_, Dec 10 2013
mathematica: Table[GCD[n - 1, EulerPhi@ n], {n, 93}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Nov 09 2015 *)
author: _Labos Elemer_, Dec 28 2000
